Let me start by understanding each part step by step. First, the first Python file. Let's see what it does.

It reads an integer n, then a string s, splits it into a list. Then uses Counter to count the occurrences of each element. Then reverses the list s. Then it looks for the element with the maximum count, and among those, the one that appears last in the reversed list. The output is that element.

#include <stdio.h>

#include <stdlib.h>

#include <string.h>

#include <ctype.h>

int main() {

    int n;

    scanf("%d", &n);

    // consume the rest of the line

    int c;

    while ((c = getchar()) != '\n' && c != EOF);

    // read the next line

    char line[100000];

    fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin);

    // process into words

    int word_count =0;

    // count words

    char *temp = strdup(line);

    char *tok = strtok(temp, " \t\n");

    while (tok) {

        word_count++;

        tok = strtok(NULL, " \t\n");

    }

    free(temp);

    // allocate words array

    char **words = malloc(word_count * sizeof(char*));

    if (!words) {

        // handle error

        return 1;

    }

    // split again

    temp = strdup(line);

    tok = strtok(temp, " \t\n");

    int i=0;

    while (tok) {

        words[i] = strdup(tok);

        i++;

        tok = strtok(NULL, " \t\n");

    }

    free(temp);

    // compute counts

    for (int i=0; i<word_count; i++) {

        counts[i] =0;

        for (int j=0; j<word_count; j++) {

            if (strcmp(words[i], words[j]) ==0) {

                counts[i]++;

            }

        }

    // find max count

        if (counts[i] > max_count) {

            max_count = counts[i];

        }

    }

    // find the a string

            a = strdup(words[i]);

            break;

        }

    }

    // free words and counts

        free(words[i]);

    }
